title: Authors and Citation
text: Chencheng Fang. Author, maintainer. Dominik Liebl. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Fang C, Liebl D (2025). fdid: Making Event Study Plots Honest: Functional Data Approach Causal Inference.. R package version 0.0.1.
code: @Manual{,   title = {fdid: Making Event Study Plots Honest: A Functional Data Approach to Causal Inference.},   author = {Chencheng Fang and Dominik Liebl},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.1}, }

title: fdid
text: R package fdid allows users implement method proposed Fang Liebl (2025)1. paper, present novel functional perspective Difference--Differences () allows honest inference using event study plots violations parallel trends /-anticipation assumptions. use algorithm -called fast fair simultaneous confidence band Liebl Reimherr (2023)2 construct simultaneous confidence band plots. turn traditional event study plots rigorous honest causal inference tools equivalence relevance testing: Honest reference bands can validated using equivalence testing pre-treatment period, honest causal effects can tested using relevance testing post-treatment period. may find presentation early version paper YouTube video. Also, users can adjust honest reference bands (see ) interactively via Shiny app.

title: fdid
text: can install development version fdid GitHub :

title: fdid
text: hereby use event study estimates Gallagher (2014)3 example. first load data package, use function fdid_scb() compute simultaneous confidence band using estimates event study coefficients, covariances reference time point, finally use generic function plot() derive figure follows.  seen, reference time example event time -1. gray area indicates time span treatment effect uniformly significant simultaneous confidence band. Traditional confidence intervals also plotted. intervals fail take account multiple testing problem, typically narrower band. estimates event study coefficients covariances, may use function fdid() estimate using original data. function allows estimation non-staggered staggered designs. particularly, consider negative weighting problem estimating event study coefficients staggered designs use carefully chosen non-negative weights sum estimates different treatment subgroups.
code: library(fdid) data(Gdata) fdid_scb_est <- fdid_scb(beta=Gdata$beta, cov=Gdata$cov, t0=Gdata$t0) plot(fdid_scb_est, pos.legend="bottom", scale.legend=1.4)

what: Example 2: Honest Causal Inference under Treatment Anticipation with Reference Band
title: fdid
text: Following Example 1, now suppose , event time tA=−1t_A=-1, anticipation treatment. use tS=−9<tAt_S=-9 < t_A compute sample estimates reference band.  anticipation event time -1, one may see time span treatment effect uniformly significant shrinks. control parameter S=2.6S=2.6, reference band can validated significance level 5%, since simultaneous confidence band strictly lies within reference band pre-treatment period.

what: Example 3: Honest Causal Inference under Differential Trends with Relative Magnitudes Reference Band
title: fdid
text: Following Example 1, now suppose , differential trend relative magnitudes control parameter M¯=1\overline{M}=1.  differential trend, time span treatment effect uniformly significant also smaller. can seen average absolute derivative functional estimate pre-treatment time quite large, reference band honest inference also wide.

what: Example 4: Honest Inference under Differential Trends with Trend Restrictions Reference Band
title: fdid
text: Following Example 1, now suppose , differential trend trend restrictions control parameter M=2M=2.  specific differential trend, time span treatment effect uniformly significant different without. can seen pre-trend, measured average derivative functional estimate pre-treatment time, quite small. Hence, inference result change much Example 1, even though control parameter infinitesimal.

what: Natural Spline Interpolation on Covariance — cov_spline
title: Natural Spline Interpolation on Covariance — cov_spline
text: cov_spline function used perform natural spline interpolation covariance matrix. See Fang Liebl (2025) detailed information.

title: Natural Spline Interpolation on Covariance — cov_spline
Natural Spline Interpolation on Covariance — cov_spline
text: cov numeric square matrix raw covariance. must contain missing values. grid numeric vector grid, raw covariance calculated. n_intrpl number points covariance interpolated. interpolation performed sequence n_intrpl equidistant points minimum maximum grid.

title: Natural Spline Interpolation on Covariance — cov_spline
text: cov_spline function returns numeric matrix covariance interpolation.

title: Natural Spline Interpolation on Covariance — cov_spline
text: Fang, C. Liebl, D. (2025). Making Event Study Plots Honest: Functional Data Approach Causal Inference.

title: Natural Spline Interpolation on Covariance — cov_spline
code: cov_mat <- cov(matrix(rnorm(250),nrow=50)) grid <- seq(0,1,len=5) cov_spline_mat <- cov_spline(cov=cov_mat, grid=grid, n_intrpl=50)

what: Estimate the event study coefficients and the covariance matrix — fdid
title: Estimate the event study coefficients and the covariance matrix — fdid
text: fdid function used estimate event study coefficients covariance matrix non-staggered staggered adoption design. staggered design, estimation suffer -called negative weighting problem, since use carefully-chosen non-negative weights consolidate estimates subgroup. See Fang Liebl (2025) detailed estimation method.

title: Estimate the event study coefficients and the covariance matrix — fdid
Estimate the event study coefficients and the covariance matrix — fdid
text: data data frame first variable outcome variable, latter two variables time unit indices. outcome variable numeric. treatment data frame first variable unit indices; second variable indicates reference time, right treatment given, unit. NA implies unit never treated/control. pre-determined covariates placed afterwards. Covariates numeric.

title: Estimate the event study coefficients and the covariance matrix — fdid
text: fdid function returns list includes estimates event study coefficients covariance. output, event time 0 considered reference period. output object S3 class "fdid".

title: Estimate the event study coefficients and the covariance matrix — fdid
text: Fang, C. Liebl, D. (2025). Making Event Study Plots Honest: Functional Data Approach Causal Inference.

title: Estimate the event study coefficients and the covariance matrix — fdid
code: data(simulated_stagger_example) fdid_est <- fdid(data=simulated_stagger_data, treatment=simulated_stagger_treatment) plot(fdid_est$beta$coef[,2], fdid_est$beta$coef[,1], type="l",      xlab="Event Time", ylab=expression(hat(beta)), family="Times")

what: Compute simultaneous confidence band for event study coefficients in functional DiD framework — fdid_scb
title: Compute simultaneous confidence band for event study coefficients in functional DiD framework — fdid_scb
text: fdid_scb function used compute simultaneous confidence band event study coefficients functional framework, together point-wise confidence intervals observable event time. adopt algorithm -called fast fair simultaneous confidence bands. See Liebl Reimherr (2023) details.

title: Compute simultaneous confidence band for event study coefficients in functional DiD framework — fdid_scb
code: fdid_scb(   object = NULL,   beta = NULL,   cov = NULL,   t0 = NULL,   df = NULL,   ci.alpha = 0.05,   scb.pre.alpha = 0.05,   scb.post.alpha = 0.05 )

title: Compute simultaneous confidence band for event study coefficients in functional DiD framework — fdid_scb
text: object object S3 class "fdid", output function fdid. provided, arguments 'beta', 'cov' 't0' ignored. beta numeric matrix two columns. first column estimates event study coefficients second column corresponding event time. estimate coefficient reference time normalized 0. cov numeric matrix covariance estimates. t0 numeric scalar indicates reference time. df degree freedom t-distributed based bands. NULL, Gaussian distributed bands computed. ci.alpha significance level pointwise confidence intervals. scb.pre.alpha significance level simultaneous confidence band pre-treatment periods. scb.post.alpha significance level simultaneous confidence band post-treatment periods.

title: Compute simultaneous confidence band for event study coefficients in functional DiD framework — fdid_scb
text: fdid_scb function returns list containing three objects: scb list includes functional estimate event study coefficients simultaneous confidence band. ci matrix includes point-wise estimates event study coefficients confidence intervals. data list stores original inputs beta cov. output object S3 class "fdid_scb".

title: Compute simultaneous confidence band for event study coefficients in functional DiD framework — fdid_scb
text: Fang, C. Liebl, D. (2025). Making Event Study Plots Honest: Functional Data Approach Causal Inference. Liebl, D. M. Reimherr (2023). Fast fair simultaneous confidence bands functional parameters. Journal Royal Statistical Society Series B: Statistical Methodology 85(3), 842–868

title: Compute simultaneous confidence band for event study coefficients in functional DiD framework — fdid_scb
code: data(LWdata) fdid_scb_est1 <- fdid_scb(beta=LWdata$beta, cov=LWdata$cov, t0=LWdata$t0)  data(simulated_stagger_example) fdid_est2 <- fdid(data=simulated_stagger_data, treatment=simulated_stagger_treatment) fdid_scb_est2 <- fdid_scb(object=fdid_est2)

what: Custom Plot Method for objects of class
title: Custom Plot Method for objects of class
text: function S3 method plot, specifically designed objects class "fdid_scb". plots simultaneous confidence band bounds honest inference.

title: Custom Plot Method for objects of class
code: # S3 method for class 'fdid_scb' plot(   object,   ta.ts = NULL,   ta.s = NULL,   frm.mbar = NULL,   ftr.m = NULL,   frmtr.mbar = NULL,   ref.band.pre = TRUE,   note.pre = TRUE,   note.post = TRUE,   ci = TRUE,   pos.legend = "top",   scale.legend = 1,   ... )

title: Custom Plot Method for objects of class
text: object object class "fdid_scb". object plotted. ta.ts numeric value indicates time point based sample estimates treatment anticipation biases computed. less equal time point units start responding future treatment. supposed greater minimal event time greater t0 object. NULL, anticipation. ta.s numeric value control parameter honest inference treatment anticipation. NULL, critical value \(t_{1-\alpha/2, df}\) \(z_{1-\alpha/2}\) applied \(\alpha\) used constructing pointwise confidence intervals. treatment anticipation defined ta.ts, value ta.s ignored. frm.mbar numeric value control parameter honest inference functional relative magnitudes. ftr.m numeric value control parameter honest inference functional trend restrictions. frmtr.mbar numeric value control parameter combining functional relative magnitudes functional trend restrictions. ref.band.pre logical value. TRUE, reference band pre-treatment periods also plotted. note.pre logical value. TRUE, note pre-treatment periods given top plot. note.post logical value. TRUE, note post-treatment periods given top plot. ci logical value. TRUE, point-wise confidence intervals also plotted. pos.legend character value "top" "bottom" indicates position legend. NULL, legend printed. scale.legend positive number defines size legend. pos.legend NULL, value scale.legend ignored. ... Additional arguments passed plot.

title: Custom Plot Method for objects of class
text: function returns plot simultaneous confidence band event study coefficients functional framework, together bounds honest inference, properly defined.

title: Custom Plot Method for objects of class
text: Fang, C. Liebl, D. (2025). Making Event Study Plots Honest: Functional Data Approach Causal Inference.

title: Custom Plot Method for objects of class
code: data(LWdata) fdid_scb_est <- fdid_scb(beta=LWdata$beta, cov=LWdata$cov, t0=LWdata$t0) cat("The reference time is ", LWdata$t0, ". If not NULL, the input 'ta.ts' in function 'plot' should be smaller than this value.", sep="") #> The reference time is -2. If not NULL, the input 'ta.ts' in function 'plot' should be smaller than this value.  ## simultaneous inference par(cex.axis = 1.4, cex.lab = 1.4, cex.main = 1.4) plot(fdid_scb_est, scale.legend=1.4) ## adding a label for Y-axis title(ylab="Effects of Duty-to-Bargain Laws")   ## honest inference under treatment anticipation plot(fdid_scb_est, ta.ts=-3, scale.legend=1.4)   ## honest inference under violation of parallel trends plot(fdid_scb_est, frm.mbar=0.4, scale.legend=1.4)

what: A simulated example of non-staggered DiD design — simulated_nonstagger_example
title: A simulated example of non-staggered DiD design — simulated_nonstagger_example
text: simulated example non-staggered design

title: A simulated example of non-staggered DiD design — simulated_nonstagger_example
text: contains two data frames. first data frame 'simulated_nonstagger_data' 8200 rows 5 columns: y Outcome variable. t Time index. 41 time periods. Unit index. 200 units. second data frame 'simulated_nonstagger_treatment' 200 rows 2 columns: Unit index. also corresponds unit index data frame 'simulated_nonstagger_data'. t0 Reference Period. NA indicates control units. x1, x2 Pre-determined covariates.

what: A simulated example of staggered DiD design — simulated_stagger_example
title: A simulated example of staggered DiD design — simulated_stagger_example
text: simulated example staggered design

title: A simulated example of staggered DiD design — simulated_stagger_example
text: contains two data frames. first data frame 'simulated_stagger_data' 4200 rows 5 columns: y Outcome variable. t Time index. 21 time periods. Unit index. 200 units. second data frame 'simulated_stagger_treatment' 200 rows 2 columns: Unit index. also corresponds unit index data frame 'simulated_stagger_data'. t0 Reference Period. can -0.5, 0 0.5. NA indicates control units. x1, x2 Pre-determined covariates.

title: Univariate two-way transformation — tw_transf
text: tw_transf function used apply two-way transformation single variable.

title: Univariate two-way transformation — tw_transf
Univariate two-way transformation — tw_transf
text: x numeric vector two-way transformation supposed performed . t vector integers indicates time. vector indicates unit.

title: Univariate two-way transformation — tw_transf
text: tw_transf function returns two-way transformed data reordered unit time.

title: Univariate two-way transformation — tw_transf
code: set.seed(100) x <- rnorm(20) t <- rep(1:5, each = 4) i <- rep(letters[1:4], times=5) df_transf <- tw_transf(x,t,i)
